name: Senator FERGUSON
content: —I rise to speak only briefly to make some comments on these proposed new sitting hours and sitting arrangements which, if adopted, will see the Senate sit more days this year but go onto the adjournment debate at 7.20 p.m. and rise by 8 p.m. I believe that the only reason that these proposed new sitting hours have been brought about is that the sitting hours that have been set down in procedures for the Senate to abide by, certainly since the time that I have been here, have not been abided by, so we have had late sittings.With the help of the Australian Democrats and minor parties, the government has negated the adjournment whenever it has suited it. So, instead of finishing at 10.30 p.m.—the hour set out in the hours of sitting for three days of the week—the government, with the help of the Democrats, has made us sit until all hours of the morning. If we had stopped at 10.30 p.m., which is the hour set down in the procedures and standing orders, a lot of the issues that have been raised, particularly those raised by my colleague Senator Herron, would not have arisen. Senator Herron has spoken many times—usually after midnight—about stress on both staff and senators. His arguments have been valid, but they have been valid only because the government, aided by the Democrats, has negated the adjournment. Therefore, the sitting hours that are laid down in the standing orders have not been abided by. Stress has been placed on both staff and senators in this place purely because the hours that have been set out have not been abided by.I can understand the reasoning behind lessening the number of hours that we sit each day. The idea is that we spread the work more evenly over more days and that we get home earlier every night. For many people this may be the case, particularly for senators and staff who live in Canberra. They will no doubt welcome the opportunity to leave here at what they might think to be the far more sensible hour of 8.00 p.m. and perhaps go home to their families or go home to have dinner. I think they are being misled if they think they are going to leave here at 8 oclock. That is another point, but I can understand why they would welcome these changes.But it seems to me that we are forgetting several very important matters. Firstly, the Senates rising at 8.00 p.m. will not mean that we will have the chance to go home at that time. Honourable senators have spoken about estimates committees and other committee hearings taking place from 8.00 p.m. onwards. In many cases that will mean that staff, including many Parliament House staff, will be required to stay on; so people who think that we will stop at 8.00 p.m. have another think coming to them. If we adopt this new sitting program in its entirety we will do away with a formal dinner break and we will be in a worse position than we are in now. Currently the situation is that in most cases senators, and in many cases also their staff, have a rushed lunch—they grab a sandwich or something else that they can have on the run—if they have one at all.If this proposed procedure is passed we will not be able to guarantee a dinner break for ourselves, our staff or the Parliament House staff. I am quite sure that many senators and their staff will still be working here at 10.00 p.m. and later. I believe the proposed procedures will have the opposite effect upon the matters which Senator Herron and others have expressed concern. If people who work here do not stop for a formal dinner break they will be even more tired and stressed than usual because they will not have a chance to have a break away from work.Senator Bourne spoke at length about senators being macho by having very late sittings, and about people working 12-hour days. I do not think that anybody who comes here expects to work the same sorts of hours as people who work in nine to five jobs outside parliament because it is just not feasible or possible. No other job drags people from all over Australia to meet here. The idea is to get the maximum amount of work done while we are here. The evening meal break is an important time for senators, their staff, and other Parliament House staff to have time out. They can sit down, eat a meal, meet with colleagues and with staff from other offices. I understand that staff find out the most interesting things during the dinner break. I am quite sure that they, as well as many senators, would miss the opportunity to have this time out to sit and talk with their colleagues and other workers.Doing away with a formal dinner break will give us even less opportunity than we and our staff have now to get out of our offices. I think particularly of the staff involved in the whips offices. My colleague Senator Teague said that a whips office could have a replacement person or have a roster system so that somebody could work during the time when the whips clerk had time off. I know that our whips clerk can quickly tell us what business is before the chamber and how quickly she can contact people to let them know what is happening. It would be an impossible position for her, and other staff like her, in their offices. This building is not designed for much social interaction. Everybody seems to be hidden away in hermetically sealed offices with very little contact, and particularly at staff level there is very little contact with other staff. The one real chance that people have to get out and mix with others is during the formal dinner break from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.The proposal to do away with that formal break for four days of the week would be very detrimental to staff and other people who work here. It is even more important for backbenchers staff because in most cases there is only one staff member for each backbencher. In ministers offices, the numerous staff can be rostered. Even if there were not a dinner break it would not have much effect because even now those staff members roster themselves for meal breaks. In the case of backbenchers, with one staff member only, that staff member usually has only a short lunch break or none at all. If these changes to procedures are passed then those staff members will not have a dinner break either.It is all very well for my colleague Senator Teague to say that they should have everything organised from 10 minutes to seven at night; if there are other things going on that night, we are still asking one staff person in an office to work for enormously long hours without a break and under constant stress. That is notwithstanding the Hansard staff. I wonder whether anybody has taken the feelings of Hansard staff into account.We are asking our single staff members to come to work in the morning and rush out to grab a sandwich at lunchtime. Now we will be asking them to rush out if they are hungry, tired or in need of a break and grab a snack to tide them over until 8 oclock. This is assuming that our staff can leave at 8 oclock. What happens if we have committee meetings and we ask them to work after 8 oclock? When are they supposed to eat and where are they supposed to eat? Currently the staff canteen shuts at 8 oclock anyway. I guess it means that Aussies will be doing a booming trade. It might be at the expense of our waistlines. If we were all at risk of dying of heart attacks because of the previous sitting hours, I wonder whether we might be just as much at risk now if we start filling ourselves up on the run with sandwiches or food that we may not normally eat.I consider that there is merit in these proposed sitting hours for the people who live in Canberra and who can actually leave at 8 oclock—they can go home at a reasonable hour and see their families—but for senators and staff from interstate, there is no home to go to. Quite frankly, I would rather have a decent dinner break from 6.30 to 8 oclock and then sit until 10 oclock or 10.30, because I will not go home any earlier if the Senate rises at 8 oclock. I will have either committee work or other work which could go much later than 10.00 p.m. After 8 oclock I would have to have dinner here or go out and have a meal somewhere else, at a restaurant perhaps.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Crane
content: —You wont get much here!
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator FERGUSON
content: —That is right. We will not get much here. Why would I and other senators in similar positions want to go back to our accommodation at 8.00 p.m. anyway? Why would we want to do it? Even if I had the facilities, the last thing I would want to do is cook myself a meal at half past eight at night. I have sampled my cooking before. Even though I am not always that complimentary about the parliamentary dining room, it is more preferable than getting my own dinner.Staff who travel with us are in a very similar position. Why would they want to go home to a motel room or their accommodation at 8 oclock at night? If they have come this far to work while we are here, we are better off putting the time into the work that we are meant to be doing. My feeling has always been that when I leave my family and home to come here, I would rather make use of every available hour here on work and get it over and done with, rather than spend extra time and more days away from my home and family. If I am here, I would rather be working than stopping at 8 oclock.In the end, despite the good intentions, I think that we and our staff will work much the same hours that we work now. The difference will be that there is likely to be more stress because we have eaten dinner on the run, not eaten at all or we end up overindulging at a restaurant late at night. It appears to me that the new sitting hours were devised by people who have more than one staff member or people who live in Canberra and have homes to go to.Apart from any other concerns that I have on my own behalf, I simply do not think it is fair on backbenchers staff and other staff who are in an office by themselves. Despite the occupational health and safety rules saying that all staff must take at least a half an hour break for dinner, the pressure will be on them to wait until at least 7.20 p.m. when adjournment speeches begin or 8 oclock when the house rises, or else have no dinner at all.There are staff who will simply have no choice at all. If they are the only employee over here, they are the only person able to do the job and they will be unable to leave their office until 7.20 p.m., if not 8 oclock. I understand from speaking to some of the staff members I know that they are none too impressed about the proposed sitting hours.There are two possible solutions for staff if these procedures go through. If the Senate is to rise at 8.00 p.m., then a full service must be made available at the staff canteen for at least an hour after we rise for interstate staff who are unable to go home for dinner. Alternatively, if a full service is not possible because of the reduced numbers, we need to consider their circumstances. It is all right for us as senators. We have access to transport in order to go out for dinner and to get home afterwards, but our staff do not all have that same entitlement.If the staff canteen does not offer a full service for a reasonable time after 8.00 p.m., I do not think it is fair on the staff who come here to pay their own way to a restaurant for a decent meal and then pay their own way to their accommodation. If we cannot provide a proper meal service in Parliament House for the staff who come here from interstate, then we must come up with an acceptable alternative.If Senator Teague is correct that there will be no requirement for staff backup from 10 minutes to seven on Tuesdays and Thursdays when government documents are under discussion, then I suggest that a formal dinner break ought to be declared for staff from 10 minutes to seven until 20 minutes past eight. This will give them time to have a formalised dinner break and these would then be the hours when the canteen should offer a full service. If committee meetings are to be held at night, they should not start until 8.30 p.m. Of the two alternatives, the second is the preferable by far, and I hope that senators will give it some consideration if, as I anticipate, these proposals are passed with the support of the Democrats and many of the sensible amendments proposed by Senator Hill are rejected.I do not believe that these procedures were devised by senators who have only one staff member. They certainly were not devised by staff who are unable to leave their offices for dinner until 7.20 p.m. or 8.00 p.m. and they certainly were not proposed by staff who come here from interstate. They were not designed by any normal person who gets hungry well before 8 oclock and does not work as well on an empty stomach. I do not know what my colleague Senator Herron would think about people who eat meals late every night. Sometimes when people wait a long time to eat, they tend to eat somewhat more than they should. These procedures certainly were not devised by senators like me who do not like being apart from our families as much as we are at present—let alone adding every Monday to the sitting schedule—and not making full use of the time when we are here. That is the most important and compelling argument of all.We have people who are drawn from all around Australia and from every state. We bring people to Canberra, which is an expensive exercise. I believe that every available hour should be used in the work of the parliament and Senate chamber so that the population of Australia gets value for its money, although some will always question whether they are getting value for their money. We should attempt to use every available hour we are here without going to ridiculous extremes. Those ridiculous extremes would never have been reached if the Democrats had not supported the government in negating the adjournment every time we reached 10.30 p.m.These proposed new rules say that we will rise at 8 oclock without the motion being put for the adjournment and I wonder just what will happen if we have a situation like we had at the end of last year. I wonder how early the Democrats will decide that they will support the government in guillotining legislation through which will restrict debate. We will have a similar situation to the one in the lower house where, on some occasions, there is no debate at all for important bills. I wonder where the Democrats would stand on such an issue, because when it came to negating the adjournment that was when the extra time that was considered to be required was made up. If that is no longer possible, how early in the session and how early in a debate on legislation will the Democrats support the government in applying the guillotine to important legislation?Senator Hill has come up with what I think are reasonable amendments which deal with some specific areas. The amendment I wish to refer to particularly is the one in relation to the adjournment debate. I support my colleague Senator Kemp, because Senator Bourne gave us the figures showing that the average time in the budget session for speaking on the adjournment debate was 22 minutes. Why would there be any need to put a time limit of 40 minutes on the adjournment debate when the average is 22 minutes? If convention is observed, we would scarcely ever go over the proposed time limit anyway.Putting the 10-minute limit on individual speakers allows the government to prevent opposition backbenchers from raising important issues. All the government has to do is bring in a couple of senators to speak for 10 minutes, have a Democrat speak for 10 minutes, and then there may be a chance for two opposition senators to raise an issue of substance during the adjournment debate and speak on it for only 10 minutes.During the debate relating to speeches on the motion for the second reading, I listened to Senator Bell speak long and loud on the importance of restricting the debate to 20 minutes, and on the same night he spoke for 28 minutes on the adjournment debate. Some standards need to be set somewhere along the way.

name: Senator Woodley
content: —It was drawn to his attention.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator FERGUSON
content: —It was drawn to his attention afterwards. The adjournment debate may be the only opportunity we have to raise important matters, and it will be possible for the government to gag that opportunity by bringing in speakers from its own side. If there was no limit, the government would not bother doing that because other speakers would be able to continue for as long as they wished.I urge the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine to support the amendment stating that there be no limit on the adjournment debate, knowing that in almost every case the adjournment will be very brief. In the event that it is necessary to raise an important issue that we do not have the opportunity to raise at any other stage during the day, it could be raised at that time. When the motion to adjourn is not going to be put, 8 oclock is the cut-off time, regardless of any other consideration.I believe that no time limit should be placed on the adjournment debate. I believe that the time will be used to effect and that it will not be abused, because it has not been abused in the past. If some very important matter comes up, the Democrats or the Greens may wish to use that time. It may be the only opportunity senators get to raise important issues. Even if the other parties cannot see their way clear to supporting our other amendments, I urge them to support the amendment which refers to not having a cut-off time for the adjournment debate.

name: Senator HERRON
content: —This is not a riveting debate. I have watched the gallery while the debate has been going on this morning and this afternoon, and there has been a constant succession of people in and out. One poor soul has been sitting there for the last half hour or so—he may be interested in what senators do and how they go about their procedures. Proceedings are being broadcast today. Perhaps there is another poor soul out there in the community who is actually listening to the debate, and I commend that poor soul. However, whether the gallery is aware of it or not, it is an important debate. What has been occurring over the three years I have been here, and all of us are aware of it, is that there has been legislation by exhaustion.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Woodley
content: —Exactly.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator HERRON
content: —Before Senator Woodley came in, in the pre-Christmas period we went past midnight discussing bills for 25 per cent of the time. On one important bill dealing with the wool levy—the government was advocating a 15 per cent wool levy; we were saying 10 per cent—at about 3 oclock in the morning Senator Woodleys party adjourned for five minutes and came back and said, `Lets split the difference: make it 12 1/2 per cent. That was a reaction to exhaustion. Nobody knew the figures; nobody had any idea of the millions of dollars involved. That is the sort of thing to which I am referring. If any more evidence is required, observe what occurs in this chamber as the time progresses past 8.00 p.m. or 9.00 p.m. and the irrational behaviour of senators after midnight, particularly towards the end of the week. One does not need to be an amateur psychologist to understand what goes on in this chamber.This is an important debate that goes to the fundamental aspects of the quality of decision making that occurs in this chamber. On one occasion this chamber made an incorrect decision late at night and sent it across to the House of Representatives, where members were equally exhausted. They rubber-stamped it and it came back again. That is the type of thing that can occur. There has to be some rationality in this.If I made one contribution to the Procedure Committee report it was setting the time limit at 8.00 p.m. There has been much debate regarding the 8.00 p.m. closure. I am not a member of the Procedure Committee, but Senator Bourne indicated that the committee drew the line there and then worked backwards. It is not just the senators who are affected by this; it is the clerks and the staff. I have spoken on this many times before—usually after midnight, as Senator Ferguson indicated, because it seemed the most appropriate time to speak about it.I have estimated that, conservatively, about 1,000 people inside and outside this chamber are affected by the sitting times, apart from the families of those people. In this International Year of the Family, what more appropriate gesture could be made to the families of everybody involved in this `whoopee land of the Senate than to give some time to the families outside this chamber by ceasing proceedings at 8.00 p.m.I cannot understood my colleagues who say, `We want to work while we are here. We are giving them the chance to work. After 8.00 p.m., they can spend all night here if they want to, but they will have that choice. At the moment with the present Senate sitting hours we do not have that choice. We have to stay here because division bells ring or quorums are required; we cannot leave the place. Like boarding school, we have to be paired to get out of the place. Under the proposed procedures, after 8.00 p.m. the choice is there. Senators can have as many committee meetings as they like—I will not be there. They can do what they like in that regard, if that is what they want. They can put a committee meeting on every night from 8.00 p.m. till 3.00 a.m.—be the guest of those who wish to do it. But, under these committee changes, one has the opportunity of saying no. I actually want to sit down and think. I want to read. I want to go and meet some people, perhaps even go to a Chinese restaurant and have a meal.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Woodley
content: —I will come with you.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator HERRON
content: —Thank you, Senator Woodley. We might actually meet on a social occasion rather than throwing invective across the chamber at one another. More sensible legislation might result. Interestingly, these are the same number of hours as the Senate is now sitting; the same number of hours have been achieved. There can be changes within the Procedure Committee report, and I support some of the amendments. I was not privy to the changes that were decided upon.Finally, I am reminded of the last election. There is a resistance to change. I am not saying that lies have been told, as in the last election, and that the electorate is scared, but we get this resistance to change. Everybody wants to resist change. We are frightened of change, so arguments are put up: `We cannot do this because somebody will not get time to eat, we will not be able to cover meal times, we will have to bolt our food down, and so on. Those matters will be sorted out. We should not resist change, and it is well known that this arrangement can be altered. It can be discussed again in the future. It is not set in stone. I came here with the impression that all these wonderful procedures were set in stone, but that is not so.Some people have voted with their feet. Interestingly, since I have been here, in a little over three years 12 of the 76 senators have left—admittedly, some involuntarily as a result of elections. There has been an enormous turnover, and it appears that the time spent here in this chamber is only an average of seven years. Senator Woodleys party would know about the tremendous numbers that are turned over. Some people quietly sneak away—they just cannot hack it. Certainly it would be a great advantage to the Australian people if we tried this experiment.The man who was responsible for the development of modern surgery, an Englishman named John Hunter, goes down in surgical history because he made the point that, `You should try the experiment and, if it does not work, it is no good. That is what is being proposed by the Procedure Committee. We can at least try the experiment and, if it does not work, we can change.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator CHAMARETTE
content: —I rise to say that the Greens, despite having problems with some aspects, support in principle this motion which contains the recommendations of the Procedure Committee. The opposition amendments have canvassed some of those potential problems. However, I very much support the sensible move—I believe it is welcome—to a more reasonable timetable which underlies the recommendations that we are considering in this debate.I was not certain whether the statement that parliamentary sitting hours have been set by the train timetables 50 years ago was accurate. I checked with the clerk—who had not heard this one—who further enlightened me as to the rationale of the present situation. Apparently, at a time when members of parliament were mainly professional and business gentlemen, who enacted their parliamentary responsibilities in their leisure hours, it was customary for them to be part time and for them to engage in the responsibilities of the parliament in the evening.That could have been true up to 25 years ago when this chamber never sat until the afternoon. Gradually the mornings have been adopted because, as we would all know, becoming a member of parliament is certainly a full-time occupation rather than a part-time extracurricular activity. As a consequence, we have not really adapted to the reality of the lifestyle or the time in which we live. For a long time Senator Herron and Senator Teague have bemoaned the severe effects on the physical and mental health of not only senators and their immediate staff but all the staff associated with the workings of this place.Members of the community have little idea of the hours of hard work that are involved in the political arena with regard to parliamentary representation and decision making. When people do become aware, via the media, of the ridiculous pressures that lead to all night sittings and early morning rises, they are appalled at the inappropriate example that we reflect to the community. Senator Herron raised the idea of legislation by exhaustion and I believe it is a very valid one. It gives the worst possible picture to the community of what our priorities are. We are seen in the community with our electoral responsibilities, but when we are debating in this place the public sees us making important decisions in a very rushed and harassed way at outrageous hours. Sometimes stern measures have to be adopted towards that, and the guillotine is one of them. The decisions that we make uphold the true significance and responsibility—
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator Panizza
content: —You supported negating the adjournment.
Speaker: N/A

name: Senator CHAMARETTE
content: —I would like to finish this and get on to the point that Senator Panizza is making about adjournments. The decisions that we make uphold the true significance and responsibility for the legislation that we debate, and this should demand that we do it in the clear light of day and without pressure, and without the slur that can be placed on us if we are in a position of considering it at all hours and in all kinds of ways.As I mentioned earlier, I support in principle the recommendations that are before us, but there are some aspects that I believe warrant consideration. The major matter concerns the curtailment of the adjournment debate which will deprive senators of legitimate opportunities for expressing matters that have not arisen at other points in the parliamentary program, and which may relate to electoral concerns and community matters. When there is a rigid timetable there is always a danger that, instead of its giving us increasing leisure and freedom, it actually constrains us so that the time allocated tends to be filled up.One of the concerns that I feel about the curtailment of the adjournment debate is that the program is being driven to a certain extent by a desire for certainty. Who can blame senators, or members for that matter, who would like to have certainty on a Thursday about whether they can catch a plane at nine oclock at night to return to their families? I believe we should respect that and provide for it.However, I am concerned that constraining all four days, with increasing competition for that time, may deprive certain senators of the freedom of speech and also lead to an overuse of the adjournment debate. Ironically, as Senator Baume pointed out, all the time allocations made by the Procedure Committee have taken into full consideration the practice that we have engaged in over the past year. In that time we had total freedom—maybe not total freedom, but certainly considerably more freedom than this program allows.The danger is that when we are offered more than we were using when we had that freedom, we will suddenly demand it all and some people will get lost in the running for the time that is available. The Greens are proposing a trial period until the Easter break. On Mondays we will continue with the unlimited practice of the adjournment, as we have had it to the present, and only have the timetabled adjournments with the 10 minutes restriction and the 40 minutes time limit for the remaining three days. I believe that this will be a way of assessing whether it is required and whether the constraints of this new program are too severe.I sincerely hope that Senator Ferguson is correct when he says that this process would not be abused if we had it for all four days. One good way of testing that is to see whether the practice leads to genuine discipline being applied, or whether it will lead to concerns that the system is being abused on the one day when it is available. I will be circulating the amendment in the chamber. It allows a trial period for one day a week—and that day is Monday—when we will put the question for the adjournment at 7.20, but the same constraints that will apply to the Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday timetable will not exist.Whether this proves to be a success or not, we will have some time to make changes. It is an attempt to see whether we need it or not. If the Senate does not consider it worthy of being maintained, we will go back to the recommendations of the Procedure Committee automatically on 3 May.My second concern has already been raised and there has been some lengthy discussion on it. It is to be found in the oppositions 11th amendment, and it refers to general business not commencing later than 4.30 p.m. on Thursdays in order not to curtail the opportunities we may have to discuss general business, and opposition, independent, Democrat and Green business. The Greens will be supporting that amendment.There will be a review of this intended program at the end of this year. This is appropriate because any timetable which we are trialing deserves to be tested under the conditions of the different sittings of the year. While that review will occur after one year, I believe that there is a requirement for some monitoring along the way. The appropriate committee to be engaged in that monitoring process is the Procedure Committee, which has put all these recommendations to the Senate.Occupational health and safety issues have implications not only for senators and their immediate staff, but also for the clerks, clerical staff, attendants and Hansard reporting staff. Their present awards and work practices have evolved under the old sitting patterns and times. It may be necessary for those awards and work practices to be altered in light of the changes that we are making.This is not only an industrial issue. We must not lose sight of the personal and social impacts. I hope that, at the appropriate time, the Procedure Committee will look at these issues. If it has not done that within a reasonable period—say, within three to six months—I will take steps to ensure that there is a review to ascertain the detrimental or positive effects of the changes that we are voting on today and which the Greens support.It is high time that we changed our routines and hours of sitting. A one-year trial period before changing standing orders is appropriate because we need to establish whether the proposed new arrangements are more appropriate at certain times of the year than at others. However, no matter what changes we make, the exercise will require goodwill on all sides of the chamber. It is possible to abuse freedom and, to a certain extent, that is what has happened over the years. It has meant that there has not always been certainty over the number of hours available for government business. Sometimes it has meant that individual senators have not been able to express legitimate concerns or raise certain issues.Just as it is possible to abuse freedom, it is also possible to abuse rules—to sabotage the best laid plans and timetables. Democracy is not enhanced by such practices. We must remember that the task of this chamber is to act responsibly and honestly as a house of review and that most, if not all, of the positive amendments to legislation occur in this chamber. Therefore, it is our responsibility to engage in practices that enhance our decision-making ability and to give legislation and the other matters that come before this chamber the scrutiny that they deserve. I move:At the end of paragraph (2), insert:Until 3 May 1994, paragraphs (b) and (c) shall apply to each sitting day except Monday, and on and after that date shall apply to each sitting day, subject to any further review and determination by the Senate..

name: Senator HARRADINE
content: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I would like to congratulate those who have made contributions to this debate and to the development of the proposals contained in the report of the Procedure Committee. Among them, of course, is Senator Herron. Being a medico, he was aware of the problems manifesting themselves amongst honourable senators as a result of the extended periods and unusual hours that we were sitting. It is heartening for me to see that there is an intention all round to do something about the situation and to get some sanity into the system, not only for ourselves but also, and perhaps more particularly, for the people other than senators and members who work in this parliament—not that I am suggesting that we do not work.By and large, I support the recommendations of the report in principle. Those recommendations are now contained in the proposal moved by Senator Faulkner. I listened very carefully to what was said by Senator Hill on this point, and I am concerned to ensure that the functions of the members of the Senate—those of review and scrutiny—should be preserved. I also listened to the responses from Senator Teague and others to the matters raised in this report.It appears to me that three matters need to be considered against the one particular requirement that we all insist upon—certainly, I do and the opposition does—and that is our power to scrutinise. Senator Hill questioned the ability of the parliament to discuss government documents in a relevant and timely fashion. Government documents will be considered but a question of time is involved. As I understand it, the new provisions deduct 30 minutes from the time presently allotted for the consideration of government documents. I am not sure that that is necessarily a good idea and perhaps some further thought could be given to it.However, I am not wedded to the amendments put forward by Senator Hill which would change the order in which government documents are to be considered. While honourable senators can obtain government documents, and presumably make press statements about them, that does not discharge our function because our function is primarily discharged in this chamber.The second matter that was given some consideration was the ability of senators to raise issues on the adjournment. This is particularly important when it comes to constituency matters. There is a limitation on the time available to honourable senators for this purpose. However, as has been pointed out, the recommendations have taken into account the average time that has been utilised for that purpose in the past. I would like to see a safety valve in place on one night—I made an interjection on this point during one of the earlier contributions—and Senator Chamarettes suggestion that it be on Monday evenings seems to me to be an appropriate one, and at this stage I would be prepared to support it.The other matter that was raised is very important. It was raised by Senator Hill and related to question time. Senator Hill moved amendment No. 12, which states in part:Questions may be put to Ministers each day until 28 questions, including supplementary questions, have been asked and answered.I strongly support that, particularly after the last two days. I will not go any further into it just at present, but I very strongly support that proposition. It is not an unattainable goal to have 28 questions, including supplementaries, asked. That has occurred in the past. I am indebted to Senator Kemp for the document he gave us. In 1980 and 1981 the average number of questions daily, including supplementaries, was 28 and 29. It was 26.3 in 1982 and 23.4 in 1983. Now it is down to an average of 22.5.Unfortunately, all of us have seen the tendency for ministers to make statements to the parliament which should be made at another time. If a matter is important it should be introduced as a ministerial statement but, quite frequently, government senators ask ministers dorothy dixers. In my view, in question time ministers should be put on their mettle by this parliament and information which is of public interest should be obtained from them. One of the most important times for this to occur is at question time. It is not being done if question time is used simply as a means of allowing ministers to get on their pet hobby horses with members of the government asking them bland questions to which bland responses are made.

content: —They could do it by press release.
Speaker: N/A

content: —They could, but, if the matter is important enough to be a ministerial statement, let it be a ministerial statement and let people be able to debate it at the appropriate time. There is provision under the standing orders for ministerial statements to be made. So I support the amendment.I do not support the oppositions proposal that we sit not at 9.30 a.m., but at 10.00 a.m. I understand the point that is being made. I have a regular committee meeting at 8.30 a.m. It might be that we will have to have that at 8 oclock. It might also be—and I do not think it is desirable—that from time to time we might have to have those committee meetings in the evening. If we do that too much it will defeat the purpose of this general attempt by everybody around the chamber to try to get some sensible hours.With those few remarks I have indicated the matters upon which I will support the opposition. I have indicated that the safety valve proposal by Senator Chamarette is worthy of merit and further consideration. I have indicated in general terms that I support the proposal that has been put forward by Senator Faulkner in the terms recommended by the committee.

name: Senator FAULKNER
role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)
content: —I want to thank honourable senators who contributed to this debate for their constructive contributions. We have certainly had those from right around the chamber, including the opposition. I single out Senator Herron and Senator Teague, who made some suggestions which are worthy of examination in the future.I would like to correct the misapprehension of some members of the opposition that the Australian Democrats appear to share a great deal of the responsibility for the negation of adjournments. In fact, it is fair to say that this was done during the last budget session as a result of informal arrangements made with all parties, including the opposition. That is true of course of most of the procedural arrangements that we make in this chamber. Any examination by honourable senators would show that a very significant number of the negations of the adjournment were done on the voices at 10.30 p.m. In fact, that occurred on 13 out of the 39 sitting days during the budget session.The major point made by the opposition in this debate was some extraordinary suggestion that it was the opposition that was making all the sacrifices and the government making none with this new routine of business and times and dates of sittings. That is simply not true. The average time available for government business in the past has been a minimum of 12 hours a week, increased only by negations of the adjournment. This new proposal would provide about 11 hours a week, on the assumption that there would be no more than one MPI a week. This would be only one-third of the total time available with this new routine of business, not the two-thirds that has been claimed by opposition senators in the chamber.Government business is the only item of business which has an open-ended start and no fixed duration under these proposals. I suppose, if there were daily matters of public importance, urgency motions, suspensions of standing orders, or lengthy debate on delegation reports or Auditor-General reports, we could find very little time for government business. That is always possible. Any system is open to abuse. We have to recognise that.But I think it is fair to say that if senators adopt an appropriate spirit about these new procedures we should be able to see achieved a regular amount of government business dealt with consistently across a session from week one through to the end of a session because there is clearly time available for that in the program.The question about the amount of time for government business is a concern that the government genuinely holds about these new arrangements, but in the interests of senators, senators staff and staff of this parliament, we are willing to give these proposals a fair go.Senator Teague made a fair point in this debate when he questioned whether we should consider the debating of legislation as exclusively government time. After all, I have noticed that more opposition senators speak in second reading debates than do government senators, and their interests are served during the committee stage of a bill. It is primarily opposition, independent and minor party senators who speak during those debates. Guaranteed time for debate of legislation is in the interest of not only the government but all senators in this chamber.Another furphy that has been raised is this question of there not being enough time for committee reports, government documents and the adjournment debate. I was convinced by the very telling statistics that Senator Bourne provided during the debate. They indicate that, on average, there will be more time available than has been needed in the past for committee reports, government documents and the adjournment debate. In fact, I am surprised that Senator Bourne did not mount a strong case to say that we were being far too generous with this new routine of business in that area. The same point does not apply to the amount of time available for government business. So it is, in fact, the government that is sacrificing time—

name: Senator FAULKNER

content: —Senator Kemp made a valid point in the debate that what the non-government parties are sacrificing is the flexibility that they had previously to speak for however long they wanted in some areas. That is true. No-one is going to deny that that is one impact. But it is part of the sacrifices that are being made by all senators in developing a compromise that has been reached through a process of consensus that unfortunately has broken down only at the last hurdle.The comment that there are no meal breaks can be dealt with fairly quickly. I do not believe it is beyond the capacity of senators, other staff supervisors and those in positions of responsibility here in the parliament to organise some sort of appropriate rostering arrangements to ensure that staff in senators offices and of the parliament do have appropriate meal breaks.As for the question of the lunchtime debates, traditionally very few senators have been involved in those debates, but it has been an opportunity that many have utilised. As Senator Bourne indicated in her contribution, there is clearly a need for that to continue because that time has been well spent by many senators. Traditionally, of course, on Thursdays we have sat through lunchtime and that has not caused enormous concern in the chamber previously.In relation to the opposition amendments, the government is not planning to go to the barricades on amendment No. 11, which will have the effect of ensuring that general business will always run for the full two and a half hours on a Thursday afternoon. The same logic is not being applied by the opposition to government business in this particular routine of business. There is no suggestion from the opposition that government business begin at a certain inviolable time and nothing can be changed. Perhaps that is not where the oppositions interests lie, so I will resist the temptation of making that particular point in this debate.The remainder of the amendments that have been moved by Senator Hill would, frankly, just have the effect of gutting this proposal. They would radically alter the proposals that have come forward from the Procedure Committee. They would destroy the very delicate compromise that Senator Bourne, Senator Teague and I worked so assiduously to develop through the processes of the Procedure Committee. I think there are arguments that can be mounted, as the Procedure Committee did, to have a consistent finishing time, but I will not be going to the barricades on that. I accept that there is a likelihood that, as Senator Harradine, Senator Bourne and Senator Chamarette have indicated, there is an attraction in that particular proposition. I stress again that these are significant reforms for the Senate.

content: —On reflection, I think that is a sound suggestion, but I do not know whether the amendments have been circulated to everyone. I will tell honourable senators what the amendments are, if that would help. Amendment No. 1 is that relating to starting times and is a separate issue. name: Senator PATTERSON
content: —The Senate is debating two nursing home bills, namely the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 and the Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993. These two bills are intricately linked. The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) sets out the circumstances for the recovery of unspent nursing home benefits in respect of the period prior to 1 July 1993 from the vendor upon the sale of a nursing home. The Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 enables this `nursing home charge to be levied.These bills extend the National Health Amendment Act 1992 which made unspent nursing home benefits a recoverable debt upon the sale of a nursing home. Previously, such overpaid benefits could only be clawed back by imposing a negative loading on the new proprietor. The changes were effectively prospective, applying only to overpayments in relation to benefits paid after the commencement date of the 1992 amendments on 1 July 1993.A year ago when this bill was being debated by the parliament the nursing home industry made it clear that the recovery of unspent nursing home benefits as overpayments from a previous proprietor should apply retrospectively as well. Whilst the coalition parties would not normally support retrospective legislation, we contended that this was a special case which would result in more timely recovery and greater protection for innocent and possibly unsuspecting purchasers.This bill takes heed of the industrys and the coalitions representations. While I do not criticise the government for introducing what is sensible legislation, this debate cannot be allowed to pass without recognising how frequently the coalition seems to be making the running in relation to important aged care reforms. This is a typical example. Late last year, Professor Gregorys funding review and the Macri documentation consultancy both lent support to many of the coalitions policy proposals. Brian Burdekins report on mental illness has reiterated many of the concerns that the coalition has continued to express about dementia care, particularly in relation to the importance of purpose specific facilities and the need for more flexible respite services.The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) provides for the collection and recovery of unspent benefits in respect of a period prior to 1 July 1993. The amount of these unspent benefits will be assessed by the secretary and recovered as a `nursing home charge levied on the vendor. These amendments will further protect the rights of purchasers, enabling them to purchase nursing homes unencumbered by debts incurred by the previous owners. As the `nursing home charge is strictly a tax, the Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 enables it to be levied on the proprietor responsible for the debt at the time of the sale.These amendments will commence on the date of royal assent; that is, they will apply only to nursing home sales that are made after that date. However, minor amendments relating to the deadlines for investigations in relation to post June 1993 overpayments will be deemed to have commenced on 1 July 1993, as will clauses relating to interest that is payable by the Commonwealth on repayments to vendors resulting from estimated debts paid to the Commonwealth that are in excess of the actual overpayment.In the explanatory memorandum to the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 the government claims that it will have little direct financial impact. It is true that moneys collected from the imposition of the nursing home charge would otherwise be collected by way of negative loadings. However, as negative loadings are often applied over a considerable period of time, it is feasible that some financial benefits will be derived as a result of more timely recovery of debts. As the Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 merely provides the mechanism for recovery of the charge, it has no direct financial impact.I would like to take a little of the Senates time to point out how the new debt recovery system, as outlined in this bill, will operate. The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) introduces a new division 2A, titled `Nursing home charge, into the National Health Act. Under this section, if an investigation upon the sale or proposed sale of a nursing home finds that a fee-reducing or unspent benefit was paid to a proprietor prior to 1 July 1993, the secretary may give notice in writing of the amount of that benefit to the vendor. The notified amount is the nursing home charge and the vendor is liable for that charge. The notice must stipulate the amount of the charge and the date that it is payable.The secretary may amend an assessment within three years of its being made. An amended assessment may be made at the initiative of the secretary or by application from the payer. If the amendment results in a reduction in the charge, the amount of that reduction is taken to have never been payable. A liable person has 42 days to lodge an objection with the relevant minister in regard to an assessment. The minister must consider an objection and reject it or allow it in full or in part. An objection decision may be reviewed under the AAT Act.Sub-section 2 refers to the collection and recovery of the nursing home charge. The secretary may extend the time for payment. However, a 16 per cent per annum late payment charge applies. The secretary may remit some or all of the penalty in special or mitigating circumstances. The charge is recoverable as a debt through court proceedings. There are specific provisions contained in the bill for the recovery of the charge from persons with joint liability, from the trustees of deceased estates, and from unadministered estates.Subsection 3 allows for the collection of the charge before the completion of a sale of a nursing home, either from the vendor, the purchaser, or both. Advance payments can occur if there is a likelihood that an assessment will reveal a vendors liability or in the event that an assessment has actually revealed such a liability.If the appropriate notice of a sale has been given: an advance payment direction can only occur upon the completion of an investigation; is limited to the purchaser; and is regarded as consideration in the sale. If an investigation is ordered due to a lack of notice of a sale, an advance payment direction may be the result of an estimate of the fee-reducing benefit, and may also include the payment of any difference between the estimated amount and the original purchase price paid by the vendor. Any advance payments made as a result of estimates are held in trust and interest may be payable if they exceed the sum of the fee-reducing benefit and any post-30 June 1993 overpayments.The bill allows the secretary to take into account any unpaid nursing home charge when setting a scale of fees and to accordingly reduce the fee that the proprietor can charge. If an outstanding charge is paid, a new scale of fees which reflects any underpaid general care benefits to the proprietor must then be determined.Amendments to subsections 65H and 65J allow the secretary to direct that pre-1 July 1993 nursing home charges and post-30 June overpayments be paid by nursing home purchasers when no advance payments have been determined. These amendments also allow the secretary to direct post-30 June 1993 overpayments to be paid by purchasers when an advance payment has been directed. The schedule to the bill replaces all references to the outdated `fee-determining benefit with the new `fee-increasing benefit in the principal act.The coalition does not oppose these two interconnected bills. As I said earlier, it was the coalition that placed on the public record the concerns of the nursing home industry about the inadequacy of the post-30 June 1993 amendments that were contained in the National Health Amendment Act 1992. This bill takes up those concerns. It must not be forgotten that determinations of nursing home charges emanate from validations of nursing home funding by the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services. Significant concerns about the departments administration of its validations program have been expressed by both the voluntary and the private sectors of the nursing home industry. On 30 September the coalition set up a Senate inquiry into all aspects of the validation of nursing home funding. The government will obviously claim that this bill will overcome some of the concerns that have been expressed by the industry about the validation process. To an extent, this is true. However, it is just as true that the success of the measures contained in this bill is inherently dependent upon the consistency and timeliness of the validation process.Professor Gregory noted the uncertainty in the nursing home industry with respect to the tasks that can be claimed under CAM, and that this is resulting in problems during the validation process. He proposes that the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services issue a clarification of the categories of CAM tasks, stating the principles that apply to each category, and giving examples of tasks that do or do not fall into that category.Sue Macri also expressed concern about the validation process in her recent work. While her consultancy was predominantly concerned with the closely related issue of the RCI and RCI documentation, she stated:Sadly, the current infrastructure established for the validation of CAM costs is not one which is viewed positively by the profession, mainly because of the negative emphasis on `lack of performance rather than `performance.I wish to put on the record that during a briefing on this bill, I asked the department whether a clause could be inserted in all written advices of estimates of determinations stating that the determination was an estimate only and advising that the principle of buyer beware should be adhered to by the purchaser. I would ask the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) to give me an undertaking that this suggestion, or something achieving the same end, will be implemented.Finally, I wish to note that a coalition amendment inserting a footnote that makes reference to section 4AA of the Crimes Act 1914 in relation to penalty units after sub-clause 65GT(5) of the bill was supported by the House of Representatives. That was in accordance with an earlier amendment to the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 that enabled users to identify the source of the new penalty units system. I would appreciate it if honourable senators, particularly ministers, when presenting legislation which refers to penalty units, would put in a clause or footnote to refer the reader back so that they know what these penalty clauses mean. It is important for us as legislators to ensure that, as far as possible, people can understand the law. One way of doing that is to see to it that they do not have to seek legal advice to find out simple things, such as what `penalty unit means.I hope that drafters will see fit to include such a footnote in all future legislation, as I believe would be the wish of this parliament. I hope that the minister will be able to address my question with respect to a purchaser about to purchase a property realising that the estimates of overpayments are only estimates and that there may be other liabilities that need to be written into any contract of sale.

name: Senator LEES
role: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)
content: —Initially I will confine my remarks to the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Bill. This is the first part of a package announced in last years budget and introduces new measures to address the problems of overservicing and fraud within Medicare.Let me say from the outset that the Australian Democrats are not impressed by this bill, particularly by the notion of peer review in this area. We are certainly not impressed by the level of influence that the AMA will be able to exert on this new process. We are not impressed by the total lack of consumer input or involvement at any level of the process.Although I have some amendments to move, I stress that, for two reasons, the Democrats will not be voting against this bill. Firstly, we acknowledge this bill does introduce a better system than we have now. It will introduce a tougher process, and therefore is certainly a step in the right direction. Secondly, we see this bill as being the last chance for the medical profession to get its house in order. If this bill does not work, and I am putting on the record here that I believe it really will not work, then the government will have to say to doctors, `That is it. You have now had every opportunity through peer review to tackle the problem seriously; and you have failed to do so.The government will then have to say it will no longer support the notion of peer review and will move to a process of outside scrutiny and control. In our view we have already gone past the point where peer review should be abandoned. The facts show that peer review has not worked in Australia or anywhere else in the world. I believe the only reason it is getting another chance is that the AMA has convinced the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) that it is worth another chance.The AMA has certainly done some very clever work to shore up its position in the aftermath of two very damaging reports about the peer review process, one by Harvey Bates for the Health Insurance Commission and the other one by the Commonwealth Auditor-General.The Australian National Audit Office report found that there was `a lack of prosecutions and disciplinary action taken against unethical practitioners. It also found that the performance of the Health Insurance Commission in this area had shown virtually no improvement since the early 1980s. The ANAO concluded that `the emergence of organised fraud and excessive servicing, protected by corporate veils and the best advice money can buy, represents a real challenge to the efficient and effective use of the health budget.The report found that the Health Insurance Commissions legislative powers were deficient and recommended changes to the legislation in order to get much tougher on fraud and overservicing. Harvey Bates reviewed the operations and procedures of the Health Insurance Commissions investigations unit and found that under existing legislation it did not provide a satisfactory base to support any positive investigations in significant cases of fraud. Bates recommended the development of a national fraud control plan—major legislative changes including giving the Health Insurance Commission adequate audit and entry powers. He also recommended increases in penalties. This is not, as he stressed, a small, minor problem.In early 1980, based on computer profiles of billing practices, the Department of Health put the extent of fraud and overservicing at least at seven per cent of the total medical benefits expenditure by the Commonwealth and the health funds. In 1982 the cost of fraud and overservicing was conservatively put at $100 million per year. If that same estimate is applied to todays budget we are up around $400 million a year. Bates estimated the cost was at least $300 million a year. I appreciate that the AMA considers these figures to be vastly exaggerated, but even if we accept the AMAs viewpoint we still have a major problem which is costing the Australian taxpayer a great deal of money.Of course overservicing is not just about money. It is also about service provision. For example, unnecessary surgery is acknowledged as an ongoing and significant problem within the Australian health care system. Until now we have not been very good at cracking down on Medicare rorts and the Health Insurance Commission has a very poor record in investigating and prosecuting medical practitioners. Between 1985 and 1992 only 43 medical practitioners were penalised for fraud. In 1991-92 only four practitioners were prosecuted by the Health Insurance Commission. However, it is worth noting that all four were indeed found to have overserviced; and more than $1 million was reclaimed from just those four cases.The medical services committee of inquiry also has a poor record in taking disciplinary action against practitioners for overservicing. From July 1985 to June 1992 only 88 practitioners were referred to the MSCI and, of these, only 51 were required to pay back any money—a total of $556,826.The Auditor-General found four possible reasons for the low level of prosecutions and disciplinary action. The first was inadequate investigative powers; the second was a lack of comprehensive and effective legislative powers; the third was insufficient training for investigators; and the last was the Health Insurance Commissions emphasis on counselling and conciliation.Both the previous health minister, Mr Howe, and the Health Insurance Commission were sympathetic to the recommendations made by the Auditor-General and Harvey Bates. In fact, in December 1992 the Health Insurance Commission began work on a legislative reform project to pick up some of the issues raised by the two reports. The commission set up an extensive round of consultations. One of the things it was asking about was the Medical Services Committee of Inquiry process. The commission was proposing to replace peer review with a much more independent process, one which was more in line with the decision-making and review processes in other Commonwealth legislation.The commission started on that process only to have the rug pulled out from under it. It seems that this was done primarily because the AMA, which had been incredibly intransigent about any sort of changes—particularly improvements—to legislation in this area for a long time, decided it was going to adopt a new and far more responsible and reasonable attitude. The AMA then put in considerable efforts to convince the minister that it was ready to cooperate.I am not sure why that change came about. It could be that the AMA saw the writing on the wall, or that the new President of the AMA, Dr Brendan Nelson, is a very reasonable and responsible person; and he was able to work responsibly with the minister to come up with a compromise deal. Whatever the reason, the Health Insurance Commission was told to stop its consultative process. The AMA was in and the Health Insurance Commission was out. Peer review, which looked to be on its way out, was suddenly well and truly back on the agenda. This has resulted basically in a total lack of consultation about this bill with anybody other than the AMA—and it certainly shows.When the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs looked at this bill late last year, a number of submissions from other professional organisations expressed concern about the influence given to the AMA over the new peer review system. There are provisions within this bill which say that the minister must consult the AMA before appointing medical practitioners to the Professional Services Review Panel, before appointing panel members to be deputy directors and before appointing members to the Professional Services Review Tribunal. The provisions do not say `may consult, but `must consult.The greatest level of AMA influence can be found in new section 83(2) of this bill which says that the minister must not appoint a medical practitioner to be the director of the Professional Services Review unless the AMA has agreed to that appointment. In other words, the AMA has been given a power of veto over the appointment of the person who is going to head up the process. I really do find that extraordinary.The AMA is not a neutral or independent group. It is, to all intents and purposes, the equivalent of a trade union for doctors. There is nothing wrong with that. I must stress that I believe it to be a very efficient and effective trade union which serves its members extremely well. I may not always agree with what the AMA says and does, but I will certainly be the first to acknowledge that it has done some very good work. I will give honourable senators a couple of examples. I have been very impressed by the AMAs recent efforts to draw attention to the link between high unemployment and poor health.It has also done some excellent work on the dangers of smoking and other related issues such as tobacco advertising and warnings on cigarette packets; and in the area of Aboriginal health it has brought to the ministers attention a range of different issues. I welcome the ministers recent involvement in the area of Aboriginal health.To put the good work aside for a moment, the AMA is essentially a union obliged to put its members interests first. To give a union veto power over the appointment of the person who is going to be inquiring into malpractice amongst its membership does not make a lot of sense.Look at it this way: imagine a bill which dealt with corruption on the waterfront where the government was setting up a panel to investigate and penalise waterside workers who were rorting the system. If the government came in here and said it was going to give the power of veto over to the ACTU, which is appointed director of that panel, everyone would be screaming from the rooftops—particularly the coalition. We would never hear the end of it.But apparently it is okay for doctors to veto the appointment of a person who is investigating overservicing by doctors. I argue that not only is that inappropriate but it sends the wrong message about the governments so-called determination to crack down on fraud and overservicing. It is not enough to be independent; one must also be seen to be independent. There should be no suggestion whatsoever about any undue influence. How can that perception of independence possibly be maintained when one organisation has the power to stand in the way of the directors appointment? The simple answer is: it cannot—and I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to change that.Another concern the Democrats have with this legislation is that there is absolutely no role in it for consumers, that is for the people who actually use the Medicare services.I have accepted with considerable reluctance the Ministers and the AMAs argument that putting consumer representatives on the review panels would be particularly difficult. But I cannot see any reason why consumer representatives cannot be included in the tribunal stages of the review process. I do not think that the medical profession should be the sole arbiter of what constitutes improper practice. The health issues centre told the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs:A committee acting in the public interest should not be concerned solely with whether a practitioners conduct is acceptable to his or her colleagues. Just as important is the issue of whether the practitioners conduct is considered acceptable to the community. The disparity between how professional groups assess the publics best interest and how lay members of the public assess their own interests can be vast and significant.The Democrats believe consumer representatives could play a valuable role on the tribunal. They would certainly make the process more publicly accountable. I think consumer groups are right when they complain that once again medical practitioners are getting a special deal from the government.These groups argue that regardless of disputes about the extent of the problem the government continues to treat illegal activities by doctors as being less serious than blue collar crime or social security fraud. Surely it is about time we started treating doctors and other professionals in the same way as everyone else who is caught ripping off the taxpayers.We did have a number of other concerns with this bill and they were addressed in the committee stage. I must again take the opportunity to say how worthwhile the Senate committee system is. This is another example of a lot of time saving for us in this chamber, and I commend the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for its hard work.I conclude by restating that I do not believe this bill will deliver, unfortunately. The reason it will not deliver is that this bill is not about public accountability; it is about accountability to ones peers and ones profession. I really do think that is a mistake. I remind the minister of the recent comment of the Hilmer committee on national competition policy, which stated:No section of the community is entitled to be a judge in its own cause.I believe those words will prove to be very prophetic in the case of this bill.

name: Senator HERRON
content: —I refer solely to the Health Legislation (Professional Services Review) Amendment Bill part of this debate. The opposition is totally opposed to fraud. This legislation has resulted because the government has failed to control fraud. It has been in government for 10 years. What has been the result of its attempts to control fraud? Firstly, it has failed to understand how medical practice is conducted. It has failed to appreciate the honesty of the overwhelming majority of medical practitioners.A Morgan gallup poll conducted last year by Time magazine questioning people with varying occupations on honesty and ethics showed that medical practitioners came out on top. I will not tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, where politicians came on that poll, but I can leave it to your imagination.The government failed in the past to control the rogues of the profession or successfully prosecute them, and its record in this regard is absolutely abysmal. In the four years prior to May 1993, 27 doctors were prosecuted and only $4 1/2 million was recovered. In fact, in relation to fraud, only $250,000 was recovered over four years.I would hate to think what the legal profession was paid to get that amount of money. So the government has failed. It has been in government for 10 years and has not been able to do anything about fraud. It was all due to Medicare. The government put up a system where there was a blank cheque and the minister says what a great success it is. Bulk billing accounts for 80 per cent of the services—just wham it through. content: —In fact, the Australian National Audit Office said it was seven per cent. We were coming down at that stage. Nobody knows for sure, although the minister put a figure on it in the budget last year. Last year, in reply to a question that I asked, he said that there would be a $100 million saving alone from pathology—as if that was all due to fraud and overservicing.The minister knows as well as I do that it was due to negotiations that were held between the Health Insurance Commission and the College of Pathologists whereby there were changes in the structure of pathology in relation to the number of pathology practices that were billing and the successive reduction in the rebates given for various procedures over a number of years. Rebates have been dropping behind the consumer price index. In fact, the Auditor-General said:There is no longer a single well established and commonly understood basis for the scheduled fee. Reductions in scheduled fee have generally resulted in reduced observance of scheduled fee by medical practitioners and increased costs for patients.So there is an incentive built in for those who feel that they are badly done by. In fact, last week in my own state a neurosurgeon quite rightly was sent to gaol for defrauding the government. His defence was that he felt he was badly done by because of the rebates that his patients were getting.The government has proposed various amendments, the thrust of which we support. Those amendments came out as a result of the referral of this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. I commend the government for taking notice of the report of the Senate standing committee. The proposed amendments were in consultation with the various objections that were raised, and we support them. We support the Democrats amendment No. 3 omitting `the minister may make, and substituting `the minister must make, because that tidies up another small aspect of it. We do not support the rest of the Democrats amendments.There are still problems in relation to this area. At least this is an attempt, in consultation with the profession, to get rid of fraud. Nobody supports fraud. It is a genuine attempt on the part of the government. We still have reservations in relation to the privacy aspect—confidentiality of patients records—which is mentioned in the Australian National Audit Office paper on this bill. But it is actually covered in a subsequent bill—which is consequent to this bill—which will come forward at a later date. With the proviso that we reserve the right to discuss the privacy aspects of the Health Legislation (Powers of Investigation) Amendment Bill 1993, we support the thrust of this bill.

content: —I table some supplementary explanatory memoranda to the government amendments. It is minor stuff but, nonetheless, it must be done. I would like to cover a few points that have been raised during the second reading debate. Allowing for the fact that this is a cognate debate, I would like first to address some of Senator Pattersons concerns on the Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill before I address the remarks made by Senator Lees and Senator Herron.I was asked about, if you like, the caveat emptor situation for prospective nursing home purchases. The arrangements that are in this bill complement the protection that is already provided by earlier amendments and, subject to compliance with the existing requirements relating to the giving of notice of sale, should provide the protection which Senator Patterson feels is necessary. The purpose of the notice period is to allow sufficient time for any liabilities to be identified and advised, obviously, to both parties but, in particular, to the purchaser prior to a sale. Failure to give correct notice is an offence. Notwithstanding such an offence, the vendor remains liable for any debts incurred prior to the sale.Obviously, because we have these new provisions does not mean that a purchaser should approach any potential nursing home sales transaction with anything less than the usual commercial diligence. On the introduction of the first stage of the amendments, the department sent a circular out to each nursing home operator and to industry representative groups explaining these new arrangements and stressing the continued importance of the buyers making sure that they are aware of any potential liability prior to the sale. The department plans to reinforce that importance at the commencement of these amendments through a further circular as well as in standard correspondence and sale situations. I think I am in a position to guarantee to Senator Patterson that, whenever the department is aware of a potential purchaser, that purchaser will be notified of these arrangements in the bill and, of course, of the need to exercise particular diligence in that situation.
